channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Israel Steps Up Offensive with Deadly Gaza Bombings
item.description: Hamas’s military wing said the bombing of about 50 targets was “a serious escalation” that “will oblige us to enlarge our attacks deeper into Israel.”
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER and FARES AKRAM
item.media:description: Israel launched an airstrike on Rafah, in southern Gaza, on Tuesday.

item.title: By Phone and Leaflet, Israeli Attackers Warn Gazans
item.description: The policy, Israel says, is aimed at minimizing civilian casualties in airstrikes. Rights groups say it does not absolve Israel from responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER and FARES AKRAM

item.title: Chinese Author Is Detained by Beijing Police
item.description: Murong Xuecun, a frequent critic of the Communist Party, had said he was expecting a visit from the police after several of his friends were detained.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: President Xi Jinping’s Solo Decision-Making Presents Challenges
item.description: American officials head to China for talks, but President Xi Jinping’s decision-making style and vision of Chinese regional supremacy, has changed the dynamic.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Abdullah Abdullah Stops Short of Declaring an Afghan Government
item.description: The presidential candidate asked his supporters for more time to decide the right course of action as Secretary of State John Kerry prepared to travel to Afghanistan in response to the crisis.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: Afghan presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah was showered with rose petals at a rally in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Paramount’s Push Into China Pays Handsomely
item.description: While “Transformers: Age of Extinction” was all but guaranteed a certain measure of success in China, its record-breaking numbers will most likely be seen as further validation of the studio’s stepped-up outreach to Chinese audiences.
item.dc:creator: By AMY QIN
item.media:description: Visitors photograph a model of Bumblebee displayed in front of Qianmen gate in Beijing as part of a promotion for "Transformers: Age of Extinction."

item.title: Tanker Hijackings Add to Tensions in South China Sea
item.description: Investigators want to know if stolen fuel is being sold for profit or is being used to finance political activities, possibly even terrorism.
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Defense Rests Case in Oscar Pistorius Murder Trial
item.description: After many delays, the case was adjourned until Aug. 7, when the defense and the prosecution will make their final submissions to the judge.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Oscar Pistorius at the High Court in Pretoria, South Africa, on Tuesday.

item.title: Holder Urges Europeans to Step Up Antiterrorism Tactics
item.description: The attorney general said European countries should try to prevent potential terrorists from traveling to Syria to fight in the war there.
item.dc:creator: By MATT APUZZO

item.title: Lawmakers in Iraq Will Meet Again to Try to Form a Government
item.description: The Parliament will convene on Sunday to try to put together a government from Iraq’s often hostile factions, two weeks after a similar effort failed.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Japanese Foreign Minister Speaks Out Against Chinese Newspaper Graphic
item.description: The foreign minister, Fumio Kishida, strongly criticized a graphic published under the headline “Japan wants a war again” that showed mushroom clouds over Hiroshima and Nagasaki, Japan.
item.dc:creator: By BREE FENG and AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: U.S. Army/Hiroshima Peace Memorial Museum, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A mushroom cloud billowing up over Hiroshima, Japan, on Aug. 6, 1945, after the detonation of a nuclear bomb by the United States during World War II.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: HSBC Draws Fire After Downgrading Hong Kong Stocks
item.description: The bank draws fire for suggesting a pro-democracy movement could cause a drop in shares listed on the city’s exchange.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE
item.media:description: Pro-democracy demonstrators staged a sit-in outside HSBC's headquarters in Hong Kong's Central financial district late July 1 into the morning of July 2, after a march demanding universal suffrage.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: Is Obama’s Foreign Policy Too European?
item.description: The president wanted to embrace Europe’s soft-power approach to foreign policy. But it doesn’t work.
item.dc:creator: By CLEMENS WERGIN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Christian Pastor Sentenced to 12 Years in Chinese Prison
item.description: A court in Henan Province has sentenced a Christian pastor to 12 years in jail on charges his lawyer said were baseless, illegal and rooted in the pastor’s attempts to help local parishioners gain justice.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:credit: Courtesy of China Political Prisoner Concern, via Chinese Human Rights Defenders.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: To Curb Prostitution, Guangdong Tries to Clean Up Massage Industry
item.description: On Monday, the Guangdong provincial government issued a series of regulations aimed at keeping prostitution out of massage parlors, including a ban on saunas and bathing rooms.
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:credit: Theodore Kaye for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Dongguan nightclub worker reading a notice from officials that the club had been closed.

item.title: Ukraine Rebels Are Retreating for Last Stand
item.description: Separatist rebels retreated Monday from positions throughout eastern Ukraine and began building barricades in Donetsk and Luhansk in anticipation of a final stand against advancing government troops.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Separatists were said to have destroyed seven bridges in Ukraine on Monday, including this railroad bridge near Donetsk.

item.title: World Briefing: Handling of Sri Lankan Asylum Seekers Criticized
item.description: Australia’s government handed over 41 asylum seekers to Sri Lankan authorities in a transfer at sea, drawing outrage from human rights groups who fear that the Sri Lankans could be persecuted in their home country.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Earthquake Shakes Guatemala and Mexico
item.description: A strong earthquake shook the border area between Guatemala and Mexico on Monday, killing at least five people and damaging dozens of buildings.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Venezuela: Stolen Matisse Painting Returned
item.description: Venezuelan authorities on Monday welcomed home a painting by the artist Henri Matisse more than a decade after it had disappeared from a Caracas museum.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: World Briefing: India: Shariah Courts Rebuffed
item.description: India’s Supreme Court ruled Monday that Shariah courts, which are run by the dictates of Islamic law, had no legal status and were not legally binding.
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: A Victory for Same-Sex Unions
item.description: The marriages of gay men and lesbians who work for the United Nations Secretariat will be recognized by the organization if they have been wed in a jurisdiction where same-sex unions are legal.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: World Briefing | United Nations: Report on Development Goals
item.description: Nearly one billion people worldwide defecate in the open, and such bad sanitation practices can endanger the health of children who live and play nearby, the United Nations said in a report released Monday.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: U.S. Official Ordered Out of Bahrain After Meeting
item.description: Bahrain told the senior United States official on human rights to end his visit early after he met with the nation’s main Shiite opposition group.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and KAREEM FAHIM

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Lawyer Charged After Trying to Defend June 4 Commemorators
item.description: A public interest lawyer, Chang Boyang, has been charged with “suspicion of illegal commercial activities” after attempting to defend several attendees at a meeting discussing the 1989 Tiananmen democracy movement, lawyers said.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: The lawyer Chang Boyang, speaking to clients he represented in China's poisoned milk powder scandal, in Zhengzhou, September 2008.

item.title: Maan Journal: Jihadis Tug at Edges of a Staunch American Ally
item.description: Poverty, unemployment and anti-government sentiment in the Jordanian town of Maan have created modest but growing support for Islamic militancy among residents.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Suleiman al-Imami flies “a flag for Islam” after his son was killed during a police raid in Jordan.
